item.title: Our first pygame - Use Sprites - part 11
item.description: IMPORTANT We jump into coding so we can learn, BUT we don’t know what we already have from the language, from the library, and we don’t know what other libraries are available. It is wise once past a cetain level of understanding to STOP, and take a look around. We should evaluate anything that is already in the game. What can be replaced by what is offered? What is reusable for later projects?

item.title: Our first pygame - tails follow head - part 8
item.description: Decisions about the Code The direction is normalized. Well in this case -1 or 0 or 1. It cannot contain distance as we use directions in calculations that expect only 0 and +/- 1. The end move position is calculated outside the class in the game loop, and the result is currently passed to the head. To move this code we need to store the tile size in the base class, everything else already belongs to the base class.

item.title: Our first pygame part 7
item.description: What we have so far Make the tail follow We have a head with a face that can eat food but leaves droppings at each place it has eaten at. Lets address that. What do we want to do? make the tail follow the head tail can be added at head or at last tail piece (changes logic and appearance of the game only very slightly) reuse the code from the player for the tail wherever possible prevent messy code fix the class names to be consitant with the standard i.

item.title: Our first pygame - continuous movement - part 6
item.description: continuous movement The game Worm should have the worm moving even when you don’t have any keys pressed, unless the game has paused. I continue using one tial at a time movement. It may be simpler to simply move in a direction, and only track the tile change when a turn is requested or when the end of the screen is reached. So we will make a small change to allow the worm to keep moving in its last direction selected.

item.title: Our first pygame - part 2
item.description: Now we get to play a little. Lets simply draw a simple background and then download some premade shapes that we can move around. First head over to kenney.nl and get the following images to follow along. The files we want are in the png/default folder. The larger images are 80x80. If you are adventurous try other images. I’m going to use individual 2d png files for each item to start.

item.title: Our first pygame - part 1
item.description: Some coding required For the first 10 posts of this series we don’t cover detail as most of this is common to the other tutorials out there. The exceptions being the screen wrap and the delta movement, which are explained to some degree. The delta movement is common to game programming in general, the screen wrap has different implementations. Everything gets re-evaluated in each new game we build with the resulting libraries of reuseable code.
